text:
Banking & Fintech  
Theme: The banking sector is one of the major pillars of the Mauritian
economy, contributing around 12% of our entire GDP. Despite the fact that
Mauritian banks are adequately capitalised, they still face the risk of
incurring high default rates if no drastic measures are implemented due to
high exposure to the tourism and household segment. There is also the risk of
featuring in the EU Blacklist, if Mauritius does not comply with the 5
remaining recommendations.

(To view the original document, please click on the link below:  
<http://reports.aiidatapro.com/brokers/SwanSecuritiesLtd/BudgetBrief2020-2021.pdf>)

Measures:  
** To comply with these 5 recommendations under the FATF, the following
measures will be implemented: (a) Risk-based supervisions in accordance with
the recommendations of the FATF; (b) Targeted outreach programmes to promote
clear understanding of moneylaundering and terrorist financing risks; (c)
Increased reporting of suspicious transactions; (d) Targeted financial
sanctions in cases of terrorist financing; and (e) Timely access to beneficial
ownership information. If Mauritius avoid this blacklist, a reputational
damage will be averted and thereby Mauritian banks can continue to attract
further foreign deposits and continue be able to provide loans denominated in
foreign currencies.  
  
** In accordance with the plan to 'Foster Entrepreneurship', the DBM Ltd will
provide Rs 10 Billion to support distressed SMEs up to a maximum of Rs 10
Million per company at a very attractive rate of 0.5% per annum. This cheap
type of financing will ensure business continuity as the SMEs might be able to
cover their fixed costs.

**  To facilitate cash flow of SMEs, Maubank will provide factoring facilities
with the help of Investment Support Programme (ISP Ltd) which will subsidise
half of the factoring fees.  
  
**  The government will provide a minimum monthly support of Rs 5,100 to each
beneficiary facing technical unemployment over the next 6 months. This whole
support is expected to cost around Rs 15 Billion and will enable those
individuals to meet their short term financing needs. Around 29% of the total
loan portfolio on our island is towards the household sector. Providing a
monthly minimum support will therefore reduce some potential defaults in
household loans.  
  
**  The announcement of a new market, as previously mentioned in last year's
budget, on the Stock Exchange of Mauritius for start-up and SMEs has been made
in this year's budget as well. This line up very well to the core message of
this budget of boosting Mauritian entrepreneurship.  
  
Other notable measures :  
**  The following new products will be introduced as per the recommendations
of the 10-year blueprint:

**  The Central Bank digital currency.

**  An insurance wrapper

**  Variable Capital Companies

**  An inaugural Sukuk issuance by the Bank of Mauritius

**  Green and Blue Bond frameworks by the Bank of Mauritius.

Outlook: While the government has announced a series of measures for SMEs, no
significant detail has been provided on the Rs 80 Billion to be invested
through the MIC Ltd. As further details are revealed concerning this Rs 80
Billion investment, the outlook on the financial services segment will become
much clearer.

html:
Banking & Fintech 
Theme: The banking sector is one of the major pillars of the Mauritian economy, contributing around 12% of our entire GDP. Despite the fact that Mauritian banks are adequately capitalised, they still face the risk of incurring high default rates if no drastic measures are implemented due to high exposure to the tourism and household segment. There is also the risk of featuring in the EU Blacklist, if Mauritius does not comply with the 5 remaining recommendations. 

(To view the original document, please click on the link below:
http://reports.aiidatapro.com/brokers/SwanSecuritiesLtd/BudgetBrief2020-2021.pdf) 

Measures: 
** To comply with these 5 recommendations under the FATF, the following measures will be implemented: (a) Risk-based supervisions in accordance with the recommendations of the FATF; (b) Targeted outreach programmes to promote clear understanding of moneylaundering and terrorist financing risks; (c) Increased reporting of suspicious transactions; (d) Targeted financial sanctions in cases of terrorist financing; and (e) Timely access to beneficial ownership information. If Mauritius avoid this blacklist, a reputational damage will be averted and thereby Mauritian banks can continue to attract further foreign deposits and continue be able to provide loans denominated in foreign currencies. 
 
** In accordance with the plan to 'Foster Entrepreneurship', the DBM Ltd will provide Rs 10 Billion to support distressed SMEs up to a maximum of Rs 10 Million per company at a very attractive rate of 0.5% per annum. This cheap type of financing will ensure business continuity as the SMEs might be able to cover their fixed costs.  

**  To facilitate cash flow of SMEs, Maubank will provide factoring facilities with the help of Investment Support Programme (ISP Ltd) which will subsidise half of the factoring fees.   
 
**  The government will provide a minimum monthly support of Rs 5,100 to each beneficiary facing technical unemployment over the next 6 months. This whole support is expected to cost around Rs 15 Billion and will enable those individuals to meet their short term financing needs. Around 29% of the total loan portfolio on our island is towards the household sector. Providing a monthly minimum support will therefore reduce some potential defaults in household loans. 
 
**  The announcement of a new market, as previously mentioned in last year's budget, on the Stock Exchange of Mauritius for start-up and SMEs has been made in this year's budget as well. This line up very well to the core message of this budget of boosting Mauritian entrepreneurship.  
 
Other notable measures : 
**  The following new products will be introduced as per the recommendations of the 10-year blueprint:

**  The Central Bank digital currency.

**  An insurance wrapper

**  Variable Capital Companies

**  An inaugural Sukuk issuance by the Bank of Mauritius

**  Green and Blue Bond frameworks by the Bank of Mauritius.         

Outlook: While the government has announced a series of measures for SMEs, no significant detail has been provided on the Rs 80 Billion to be invested through the MIC Ltd. As further details are revealed concerning this Rs 80 Billion investment, the outlook on the financial services segment will become much clearer.
